Q: Is it possible to move a Conan package from conan-center to a private registry on an air-gapped network? A:

It's not really a conan question, because your air-gaped system needs some way to allow data to go from non-air-gaped to air-gaped and this is not specific to conan.

If the only bridge you have available is file copy, then you can copy the conan cache from an ungapped system for this purpose. The conan cache is usually in the ~/.conan2 directory.

However, if you know what your air-gapped system provides for this purpose, they you have only solved 1 percent of the conan air-gaping problem. The real conan air-gapping problem is that conan packages usually do not contain code but urls referencing those sources. This is a huge pita with most package managers and the solutions they recommend are less than practical.

Are there package management system that solved this problem? I have not tried Nix but I have been told it has. Note that Nix is not just a system package manager like rpm, apt, arch etc... Would be great is someone can leave a comment about their experiences with Nix in general and regarding air-gaping.

Update: Just to not discourage you from using Conan, I do use conan air-gaped since a few days only. I find the recommended way unnecessarily ugly, it works, but aside from this, I am really happy with Conan.

Q: "TypeError: expected string or bytes-like object, got 'type'" error with SQLAlchemy query A:

It's not clear where the error you mentioned is being generated. There might be an overlap of certain properties. To help, I've written an example of how I envision your database and how it works for me.

I'm assuming you have two tables (authors & pseudonyms), each with an ID column that corresponds to the primary key. Because of the reference between them, pseudonyms also has a foreign key author_id.

Your code for the models should look something like this.

class Author(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'authors'
    author_id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    author_name = db.Column(db.String, nullable=False)
    pseudonyms = db.relationship('Pseudonym')
    # ...

class Pseudonym(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'pseudonyms'
    pseudonym = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    author_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('authors.author_id'))
    # ...

A translation of the SQL query listed in your question corresponds to the following code using the Legacy Query Interface.

author_id = 1
authors = Author.query\
    .join(Pseudonym, Pseudonym.author_id == Author.author_id) \
    .filter(Pseudonym.pseudonym == author_id) \
    .all()
print(authors)

I hope that after comparing your code with mine, troubleshooting will be easier and more successful.

Q: Printing a stack trace of a hung thread A:

One problem is that the state of the stream in the C++ runtime library could be inconsistent at the time the signal handler is executed. Therefore, you should not be calling any stream I/O functions from the C++ standard library in the signal handler, as this may cause the program to crash.

However, depending on which platform you are using, it is likely possible to print output from the signal handler in a safe way.

For example, on Linux, it is safe to call functions that are explicitly listed as async-signal-safe. The system call write (which bypasses the C++ stream) is a function that is listed as async-signal-safe, so it allows you to print output safely from a signal handler.

Another problem is that std::stacktrace uses the default memory allocator, which could also be in an inconsistent state when the signal handler is executed. Therefore, using it from the signal handler may result in a crash.

However, it is possible to create a std::basic_stacktrace object which uses your own memory allocator instead of the default memory allocator. If this allocator of yours is only used by the signal handler, and the signal handler is guaranteed to not be called again before the first call has finished executing (see reentrancy), then it should be safe to use this memory allocator, as long as this memory allocator does not call any functions that are not async-signal-safe.

This means that on Linux, your memory allocator cannot call mmap from inside the signal handler, because that function is not listed as async-signal-safe. However, your allocator is allowed to for example allocate memory from a memory buffer that was previously allocated using the default memory allocator outside the signal handler.

But doing all of this is rather complicated. Therefore, in the case described in the question, the easiest thing to do would probably be to create a core dump of the process, and to generate a stack trace from that core dump.

Q: How to put a script in the head tag in next.js? A:

If you use the Next.js <Script> component, it will automatically insert an async script into the <head>.
However, if you try to use a regular JavaScript <script> tag, the npm run build process will fail.

Solution:
Use a regular <script> tag along with /* eslint-disable-next-line */ to bypass the linting error. Now Next will add your script synchronously without async or defer props

{/* eslint-disable-next-line @next/next/no-sync-scripts */}
<script src="YOUR_DOT_JS_FILE_URL_HERE" />
